lines.text: Money is all that matters. Well, I can get money! It's easy to get money! All you have to do... is kill.
My boy, I've heard such ideas, a long time ago. They are dreams - beautiful dreams, I know, but dreams nonetheless.
Was it a dream that once I knew a man who said "Love thy neighbor as thyself"?
There never was such a man, I tell you.
Don't lie to him, Marcus. There was such a man.
What happened to him?
I crucified Him.
He still believes in things.
And you and I are wiser? Perhaps... What is truth?
I am innocent of the blood of this just man.

[pandering]
If you're a rich man, a few coppers wouldn't interest you.
[giving Marcus a coin]
This is for your work...
[he gives him a second copper]
... and this is for saving my life.

[laughing with contempt]
Just about what the job is worth!
You remind me of an acrobat in the arena walking on a rope stretched high in the air.
Walking on a rope?
Yes, a rope no wider than my thumb.

[laughing]
I'm not walking on a rope.
Oh, yes, you are. Every poor man is. You think you're balanced nicely, but only money can make you safe. Some little unexpected thing, and you're down... smashed!
I don't think you should look down on me, my friend. Aren't we in the same business? We both furnish amusement for the people.
I risk my life with the man I'm fighting. You buy and sell wretches to be slaughtered as a spectacle. I'm not proud of myself, but, by Jupiter, compared to you I'm a holy man.
You will never be an old one. It isn't bravery that survives; it's brains.
Yes, it is well known that the rat lives longer than the lion, but who wants to be a rat? I wouldn't do your dirty work - not to save my life!
If you don't want my money, what will you give to the poor?
Myself.
What do you keep behind these locks and bolts?
My fortune, excellency. It's a safe place.
Would the prefect like to inspect the barbarians - the Britons who are to fight tomorrow?
Yes.
[to the prefect]
Captives from Agricola's campaign.
I wonder why we Romans trouble ourselves with that wretched island? After it's conquered, what good is it?
Don't you believe we can ever civilize the Britons?
Those people? They'll always be barbarians. What will they ever do?

[carelessly, after Marcus has thanked him for a payment]
What have I done/
[Suddenly stricken with guilt]
What have I done?
Excellency!
Forgive me. I am not myself. Just now I have been forced to condemn a Man. Poor Man, I found no fault in Him. But I must try to keep the peace.
